context_of_use: The IFA configures the system to integrate existing systems, maintain reliability for high concurrent usage, and restrict user access to relevant tools in order to improve data consistency, performance, and usability.
stakeholders_and_interests: ifa: Wants to avoid redundant data storage by integrating existing systems, maintain reliable operation for at least 50,000 concurrent users, and restrict user access to only relevant tools to reduce confusion.
System Users: Want a satisfactory user experience with reliable performance and clear, non-confusing access to tools.
System Operations and Infrastructure Stakeholders: Want system configuration that supports specified reliability targets and predictable load characteristics.
Security and Compliance Stakeholders: Want user access restrictions configured to align with least-privilege principles and organizational policies without introducing unauthorized access.
description: This use case describes how the IFA configures the system to integrate existing systems, maintain reliability for a large number of concurrent users, and restrict user access to only relevant tools, thereby improving data consistency, performance, and usability.
triggering_event: The ifa decides to configure or update system settings related to integration of existing systems, reliability parameters, and user access restrictions.
preconditions: The IFA Central Management System is operational and reachable by the ifa.
The ifa is authenticated in the system.
The ifa has configuration privileges for system integration, reliability, and access control settings.
At least one existing external system is available for potential integration.
A defined set of system tools and user roles exists within the system.
postconditions: Configured integration settings between the IFA Central Management System and selected existing external systems are stored and active.
Configured reliability-related settings that support at least 50,000 concurrent users are stored in the system configuration.
Configured user access restrictions that map user roles or categories to relevant tools are stored and enforced by the system.
Subsequent system operations use the updated configuration for data access, performance characteristics, and tool availability for users.
assumptions: It is assumed that existing external systems expose interfaces compatible with the IFA Central Management System and that no new integration capabilities beyond those implied by integration configuration are required.

It is assumed that the ability to maintain system reliability for at least 50,000 concurrent users is already supported by the underlying infrastructure and that this use case only covers configuration of related parameters rather than infrastructure provisioning.

It is assumed that user access restriction is implemented through existing role- or group-based access control mechanisms, and that this use case only configures mappings between user categories and tools, without defining new access control mechanisms.
It is assumed that the ifa interacts with a configuration user interface provided by the IFA Central Management System, and that detailed UI design is outside the scope of this use case.
It is assumed that changes to configuration settings take effect either immediately or according to an existing system-defined activation policy, which is not altered by this use case.
requirements_met: The system shall allow the ifa to configure integration with different existing systems to reduce redundant data storage.
The system shall use the configured integration settings to access data from existing systems instead of storing redundant copies where applicable.
The system shall allow the ifa to configure reliability-related parameters to support at least 50,000 concurrent users.
The system shall apply reliability-related configuration settings during operation to help maintain a satisfactory user experience under high concurrent load.
The system shall allow the ifa to configure restrictions so that each user category has access only to tools relevant to that category.
The system shall enforce configured user access restrictions so that users are presented only with relevant tools, thereby reducing confusion.
outstanding_issues: Specific technical mechanisms and protocols for integrating existing external systems need to be defined.
Quantitative performance parameters and monitoring thresholds required to maintain reliability for at least 50,000 concurrent users need to be detailed.
Detailed policies for mapping user categories to relevant tools and how these mappings are governed over time need to be established.
Rules and procedures for validating and approving configuration changes, including change control and audit requirements, need to be clarified.
main_flow: 1. ifa selects the system configuration function for integration settings → System displays available configuration options for integrating existing external systems and shows current integration status.

2. ifa selects one or more existing external systems to integrate and specifies integration parameters (such as endpoints, credentials, and data domains to be shared) → System validates the provided integration parameters with the selected external systems and indicates whether the parameters are syntactically and logically acceptable.

3. ifa confirms the integration configuration for the selected existing external systems → System saves the confirmed integration configuration and activates it for subsequent data access to reduce redundant data storage.

4. ifa navigates to the reliability configuration section of the system configuration → System displays reliability-related settings, including parameters required to support at least 50,000 concurrent users.

5. ifa specifies target reliability-related parameters intended to support at least 50,000 concurrent users (such as maximum concurrent user target and related performance thresholds) → System validates the specified reliability-related parameters against predefined limits and checks them for internal consistency.
6. ifa confirms the reliability-related configuration settings → System saves the confirmed reliability-related configuration settings and prepares to apply them to subsequent system operations.
7. ifa navigates to the user access configuration section for tool visibility and permissions → System displays available user categories and associated tools, along with current access restrictions.

8. ifa selects user categories and specifies which tools are relevant and should be accessible to each selected category → System validates the specified access restrictions, ensuring that the configuration is internally consistent with existing role and permission structures.

9. ifa confirms the configured user access restrictions for the selected user categories → System saves the confirmed user access configuration and enforces it so that users only see and can access tools relevant to their category.

10. ifa reviews a summary of all newly applied configuration changes → System displays a consolidated summary of integration, reliability, and access restriction settings that have been saved and confirms successful completion of the configuration process.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 2): ifa chooses to configure integration parameters for only a subset of available data domains of a selected existing external system instead of full integration. System validates the subset configuration, indicates that only the selected data domains will be accessed to reduce redundancy, and returns to Step 3 for confirmation.

AF-2 (from Step 5): ifa chooses to adjust only a subset of reliability-related parameters while leaving other parameters at their existing values. System validates only the modified parameters, maintains unchanged parameters as currently configured, and then proceeds to Step 6 for confirmation.

AF-3 (from Step 8): ifa chooses to copy user access configurations from an existing user category to another category and then make minor adjustments to tool access. System applies the copied configuration, allows adjustments, validates the resulting configuration for internal consistency, and then proceeds to Step 9 for confirmation.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 2): The system cannot validate the provided integration parameters due to connection failure or invalid credentials. System displays an error message indicating that integration validation failed, logs the failure, does not save the invalid parameters, and returns the ifa to Step 2 to correct the integration parameters.

EF-2 (from Step 5): The specified reliability-related parameters exceed allowed system limits or conflict with existing configuration constraints. System rejects the invalid reliability settings, explains the constraint violation, keeps previous reliability settings unchanged, and returns the ifa to Step 5 to adjust the parameters.

EF-3 (from Step 8): The specified user access restrictions would result in a user category having no access to any tools or having access that conflicts with essential system operations. System rejects the inconsistent access configuration, presents details of the inconsistency, preserves the previous access settings for the affected user category, and returns the ifa to Step 8 to revise the configuration.

EF-4 (from Step 3): Activation of integration configuration fails due to an internal system error. System logs the error, marks the associated integration as inactive, informs the ifa that integration activation failed, and terminates the use case with integration configuration not applied but previously active settings preserved.

EF-5 (from Step 6): Application of reliability-related settings fails due to an internal system error. System logs the error, maintains previously active reliability settings, informs the ifa of the failure, and terminates the use case with prior reliability configuration still in effect.

EF-6 (from Step 9): Enforcement of new user access restrictions fails due to an internal system error. System logs the error, continues to apply the previous access configuration, informs the ifa of the issue, and terminates the use case without applying the new access configuration.
information_for_steps: 1. Configuration section identifier, list of available integration configuration options, current integration status data.
2. Selected external system identifiers, integration endpoints, authentication credentials, data domain selection, validation result flags.
3. Confirmed integration configuration parameters, activation status of integration settings, integration configuration version or timestamp.
4. Reliability configuration section identifier, list of reliability-related parameters, current reliability configuration values.
5. Target concurrent user value (including at least 50,000), performance thresholds, capacity-related parameters, validation result flags for reliability settings.
6. Confirmed reliability configuration parameters, stored reliability configuration record, activation status of reliability settings.
7. User category identifiers, tool identifiers, current mappings between user categories and tools, access configuration options.
8. Selected user categories, selected tools per category, proposed access mappings, validation result flags for access configuration.
9. Confirmed user access mappings, stored access control configuration, enforcement status for restrictions.
10. Consolidated summary of integration settings, reliability settings, and user access mappings, confirmation status messages, configuration change identifiers or timestamps.
